metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: Chirality and isomers in determining medicine effectiveness

chirality-definition.name: Chirality Definition
chirality-definition.correct: A chiral molecule cannot be superimposed on its mirror image, like left and right hands

all molecules are chiral.fix: Only molecules lacking a plane of symmetry are chiral
all molecules are chiral.action: Look for internal mirror planes - if present, molecule is achiral

chirality means having double bonds.fix: Chirality relates to 3D arrangement, not bond types
chirality means having double bonds.action: Chirality depends on spatial arrangement, not presence of π bonds

chiral molecules are mirror images of th.fix: Chiral molecules have mirror images that CANNOT be superimposed
chiral molecules are mirror images of th.action: Key test: can you superimpose object and mirror image?

persistent.gap: Not understanding chirality as non-superimposable mirror images
persistent.action: Like hands: mirror images but cannot be superimposed

chiral-centre.name: Chiral Centre
chiral-centre.correct: A chiral centre is a carbon bonded to four different groups

requires four carbons.error: Confusing attached carbons with different groups
requires four carbons.fix: Need four DIFFERENT groups attached, not specifically four carbons
requires four carbons.action: Check: are all four attached groups different?

any carbon can be chiral.fix: Only carbons with four different substituents can be chiral centres
any carbon can be chiral.action: If any two groups are identical, carbon is not a chiral centre

nitrogen cannot be a chiral centre.fix: Nitrogen and other atoms can also be chiral centres in some cases
nitrogen cannot be a chiral centre.action: Most common is sp³ carbon, but not exclusive

persistent.action: Look for C with 4 different substituents: C(A)(B)(C)(D)

enantiomers.name: Enantiomers
enantiomers.correct: Enantiomers are non-superimposable mirror images with identical physical properties except optical rotation

have different melting points.fix: Enantiomers have same mp, bp, solubility; differ only in optical rotation direction
have different melting points.action: Only optical rotation and interaction with chiral environments differ

are the same compound.action: Same formula and connectivity but different 3D arrangement

always have different biological activit.fix: Enantiomers may have same, different, or opposite biological activities
always have different biological activit.action: Biological activity depends on chiral receptor interactions

persistent.action: Mirror images, non-superimposable, same properties except optical rotation

optical-rotation.name: Optical Rotation
optical-rotation.correct: Chiral compounds rotate plane-polarised light; enantiomers rotate equally but in opposite directions

all compounds rotate light.error: Only chiral compounds are optically active
all compounds rotate light.fix: Achiral compounds and racemic mixtures do not rotate light
all compounds rotate light.action: Optical activity is a property of chiral compounds only

rotation indicates which enantiomer is b.error: Confusing rotation direction with biological activity
rotation indicates which enantiomer is b.fix: Rotation direction (+ or -) doesn't predict biological activity
rotation indicates which enantiomer is b.action: R/S configuration and +/- rotation are separate classifications

stronger rotation means purer compound.fix: Specific rotation is constant for a compound; observed rotation depends on concentration
stronger rotation means purer compound.action: Compare to known specific rotation value

persistent.gap: Not understanding optical activity of enantiomers
persistent.action: One enantiomer rotates light +; other rotates same amount -

racemic-mixture.name: Racemic Mixture
racemic-mixture.correct: A racemic mixture contains equal amounts of both enantiomers and shows no net optical rotation

is optically active.fix: 50:50 mixture has no net rotation - rotations cancel

has different properties from pure enant.fix: Racemate has same mp, bp, etc. as enantiomers (usually)
has different properties from pure enant.action: Main difference is no optical rotation

is the preferred pharmaceutical form.fix: Single enantiomers often preferred for better efficacy and safety
is the preferred pharmaceutical form.action: Racemic drugs may have issues from inactive or harmful enantiomer

persistent.action: 50:50 enantiomer mix; rotations cancel; optically inactive

biological-recognition.name: Biological Recognition
biological-recognition.correct: Biological receptors are chiral and can distinguish between enantiomers

receptors interact equally with both ena.fix: Chiral receptors have specific 3D shapes that fit one enantiomer better
receptors interact equally with both ena.action: Like a right hand fits a right glove better than a left glove

enantiomers always have opposite effects.fix: One may be active, other inactive, or both active but different
enantiomers always have opposite effects.action: Effect depends on specific receptor interaction

body doesn't distinguish enantiomers.fix: Enzymes, receptors, and transporters are all chiral and discriminate
body doesn't distinguish enantiomers.action: Chiral recognition is fundamental to biochemistry

persistent.action: Chiral receptors fit one enantiomer better → different effects

thalidomide-case.name: Thalidomide Case
thalidomide-case.correct: Thalidomide disaster showed one enantiomer was therapeutic while the other caused birth defects

both enantiomers were safe.fix: One enantiomer caused severe birth defects (teratogenic)
both enantiomers were safe.action: Led to stricter regulations on chiral drug testing

separating enantiomers would have solved.fix: Thalidomide enantiomers interconvert in the body, so pure enantiomer isn't a solution
separating enantiomers would have solved.action: Some chiral drugs racemise in vivo

this is the only example of enantiomer d.fix: Many chiral drugs have enantiomers with different activities
this is the only example of enantiomer d.action: Thalidomide is famous example but not unique

persistent.gap: Not appreciating pharmaceutical importance of chirality
persistent.action: Thalidomide: one enantiomer therapeutic, other teratogenic

single-enantiomer-drugs.name: Single-Enantiomer Drugs
single-enantiomer-drugs.correct: Single-enantiomer drugs contain only the active enantiomer, improving efficacy and reducing side effects

always twice as potent as racemate.fix: Dose adjustment depends on whether inactive enantiomer has effects
always twice as potent as racemate.action: May be more than 2× if inactive enantiomer causes side effects

impossible to manufacture.fix: Asymmetric synthesis, resolution, and biocatalysis produce single enantiomers
impossible to manufacture.action: Modern methods can produce enantiopure drugs economically

offer no advantages.fix: Single enantiomers can have better efficacy, fewer side effects, simpler dosing

persistent.action: Pure active form: cleaner pharmacology, potentially fewer side effects

sentences.text: A chiral molecule cannot be {{d1}} on its mirror image, similar to how left and right {{d2}} are mirror images but not identical.

d2.tooltip: Hands are the classic chirality example

sentences.text: A chiral centre is typically a {{d1}} atom bonded to {{d2}} different groups.

d1.tooltip: Most common chiral centres are carbon

sentences.text: Enantiomers are {{d1}} that are {{d2}} mirror images of each other.

d1.tooltip: Enantiomers are a type of stereoisomer

sentences.text: Enantiomers have identical physical properties except for the direction of {{d1}} of plane-polarised light.

d1.tooltip: Enantiomers rotate light in opposite directions

sentences.text: One enantiomer rotates light {{d1}} (+) and the other rotates it {{d2}} (-) by the same amount.
A racemic mixture contains {{d1}} amounts of both enantiomers and shows {{d2}} net optical rotation.
Biological receptors are {{d1}} and can distinguish between {{d2}}.
Thalidomide showed that one enantiomer was {{d1}} while the other caused severe {{d2}}.
Single-enantiomer drugs contain only the {{d1}} form, potentially improving {{d2}} and reducing side effects.
To identify a chiral centre, look for a carbon with {{d1}} different substituents. If any two substituents are {{d2}}, the carbon is not a chiral centre.
Alanine (CH₃-CH(NH₂)-COOH) has a chiral centre because the central carbon has {{d1}} different groups attached: -CH₃, -{{d2}}, -COOH, and -H.

d2.tooltip: Amine is one of the four groups

sentences.text: A molecule can have multiple chiral centres. With n chiral centres, there are up to {{d1}}ⁿ possible stereoisomers.
The drug ibuprofen exists as two enantiomers. The {{d1}}-ibuprofen is the active pain reliever, while {{d2}}-ibuprofen is initially inactive but slowly converts to the active form in the body.

d2.tooltip: R-ibuprofen converts to S in body

sentences.text: Enantiomers have identical {{d1}}, {{d2}}, and {{d3}}, but interact differently with chiral environments like receptors and enzymes.
A polarimeter measures optical rotation. The observed rotation depends on {{d1}} and {{d2}} of the sample, while specific rotation is a {{d3}} property.

d3.tooltip: Specific rotation is constant for compound

sentences.text: The thalidomide tragedy occurred because the drug was sold as a {{d1}}. The (R)-enantiomer was a sedative, while the (S)-enantiomer was {{d2}}. This led to stricter {{d3}} on chiral drugs.
When a chiral drug binds to a receptor, the interaction involves a {{d1}}-point attachment. If the drug doesn't match the receptor's {{d2}}, binding is weaker or absent.
Developing single-enantiomer drugs requires {{d1}} synthesis or {{d2}} of racemates. The benefit is potentially {{d3}} doses with fewer side effects.
Many drugs contain chiral centres. For example, adrenaline has {{d1}} chiral centre(s), giving rise to {{d2}} enantiomers. The body produces and uses only the {{d3}}-adrenaline form.

The amino acid thalidomide was derived from, glutamic acid, has {{d1}} chiral centre. In the body, thalidomide undergoes {{d2}}, meaning pure enantiomer would still convert to racemate, complicating the safety issue.

d1.tooltip: Glutamic acid has one chiral centre

sentences.text: Chiral drugs can exhibit different pharmacological profiles: (1) one active, one inactive; (2) both active with {{d1}} effects; (3) one active, one {{d2}}; or (4) both active for {{d3}} conditions.

d1.tooltip: Some enantiomer pairs have same activity

d2.tooltip: Worst case: one enantiomer is harmful

sentences.text: The β-blocker propranolol: (S)-propranolol blocks {{d1}} receptors (therapeutic), while (R)-propranolol has {{d2}} activity but contributes to {{d3}} effects. Selling as racemate simplifies manufacturing.

d3.tooltip: Inactive enantiomer may cause side effects

sentences.text: Modern drug development often focuses on single enantiomers because: (1) cleaner {{d1}} profile, (2) potentially {{d2}} effective doses, (3) reduced burden on patient's {{d3}} system, and (4) extended {{d4}} protection.

d2.tooltip: Don't need to dose inactive form

sentences.text: Regulatory agencies now require testing of {{d1}} enantiomers of chiral drugs. Companies must demonstrate the {{d2}} and {{d3}} profile of each enantiomer before approval, regardless of whether the final product is a racemate or single enantiomer.

explanations.chirality-definition: Chiral molecules cannot be superimposed on their mirror images, like left and right hands.
explanations.chiral-centre: A chiral centre is typically a carbon bonded to four different groups.
explanations.enantiomers: Enantiomers are non-superimposable mirror images with identical physical properties except optical rotation.
explanations.optical-rotation: Chiral compounds rotate plane-polarised light; enantiomers rotate equally but in opposite directions.
explanations.racemic-mixture: Racemic mixture = 50:50 enantiomers; no net optical rotation as rotations cancel.
explanations.biological-recognition: Chiral receptors distinguish enantiomers, leading to different biological activities.
explanations.thalidomide-case: Thalidomide showed one enantiomer therapeutic, other teratogenic; led to stricter regulations.
explanations.single-enantiomer-drugs: Single-enantiomer drugs contain only the active form, improving efficacy and reducing side effects.
